message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are indicative of biliary obstruction or blockage. The elevated bilirubin and direct bilirubin levels suggest a hepatic cause, while the mass in the right upper abdomen and fusiform dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct suggest a biliary cyst. Biliary atresia would present in the neonatal period, and the other options are less likely given the clinical findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest biliary obstruction, which can be caused by a biliary cyst. Biliary atresia is also a possibility, but it usually presents earlier in infancy. Hepatic abscess and pancreatic pseudocyst would have different laboratory findings and imaging results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is suggestive of a biliary cyst, which can cause jaundice, abdominal mass, and dilated bile ducts. Biliary atresia is a more severe condition that presents in newborns, and it would not cause an abdominal mass. Hepatic abscess and pancreatic pseudocyst would not explain the jaundice and bile duct dilation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, such as yellow discoloration of the skin and darkening of urine, suggest liver dysfunction, and the mass in the right upper abdomen suggests a biliary cyst. Biliary atresia would present with jaundice and pale stools. Hepatic abscess and pancreatic pseudocyst typically present with fever and pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of jaundice, loss of appetite, vomiting, and scratching suggest a liver or gallbladder problem. The serum studies show elevated bilirubin levels, which supports the diagnosis of a biliary problem. Abdominal ultrasonography shows dilation of the gall bladder and a fusiform dilation of the extrahepatic bile duct, which are characteristic of biliary cysts. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis for this patient is a biliary cyst.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including yellow discoloration of skin, loss of appetite, vomiting, and scratching of abdomen and arms, suggest the likely diagnosis is biliary cyst. The elevated total bilirubin and direct bilirubin, as well as the dilation of the gall bladder and extrahepatic bile duct, support this diagnosis. Biliary atresia is another possible diagnosis, but it usually presents in the neonatal period with jaundice and acholic stools, and the liver function test results are typically more abnormal. Hepatic abscess and pancreatic pseudocyst are less likely given the patient’s history and symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory results suggest obstructive jaundice. The mass in the right upper abdomen suggests a possible biliary cyst. Biliary atresia would have presented earlier, within the first few weeks of life. Hepatic abscess and pancreatic pseudocyst do not typically cause obstruction of the bile duct. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is biliary cyst.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of jaundice, loss of appetite, vomiting, and scratching suggest a problem with the biliary system. The dilated gallbladder and extrahepatic bile duct on ultrasound support a diagnosis of biliary cyst. Biliary atresia would have presented with symptoms earlier in life and would have shown complete obstruction of the biliary system. Hepatic abscess and pancreatic pseudocyst would not present with the same symptoms and findings on ultrasound.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest biliary obstruction, and the most common cause of biliary obstruction in children is biliary cyst. Biliary atresia can also cause biliary obstruction but it usually presents in the neonatal period. Hepatic abscess and pancreatic pseudocyst do not cause biliary obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of jaundice, dark urine, light stools, and a mass in the right upper abdomen, along with elevated bilirubin levels and dilation of the gall bladder and extrahepatic bile duct on abdominal ultrasonography, suggests the most likely diagnosis is biliary cyst. Biliary atresia would present earlier in life (usually within the first few months) and usually have elevated AST and ALT levels. Hepatic abscess and pancreatic pseudocyst are unlikely given the presentation and laboratory findings.
